site.title: One Breath Partnership
site.description: One Breath Partnership elevates the work for clean air for everyone in Houston, Harris County and Texas.
site.home_header: Working for clean air every day for everyone.

node.title: We're good neighbors. Why won't Houston's industry be?

children.text: The private companies that benefit from operating in Texas shouldnâ€™t be allowed to abuse and take advantage of public property and pollute our water and air.

mainImage.alt: Under current state law, the maximum fine TCEQ can levy for violating air permits is just $25,000 per day. Photo: Julie Dermansky.
mainImage.caption: Under current state law, the maximum fine TCEQ can levy for violating air permits is just $25,000 per day. Photo: Julie Dermansky.

node.title: Why doesn't TCEQ fine polluters more?

children.text: In Texas, it can cost less to be caught polluting than to continue to pollute. And industry is banking on that.

node.title: You don't want to live near a concrete batch plant. But TCEQ lets it happen too easily.

children.text: The overly permissive state environmental agency isn't protecting Texans from the potentially harmful and hazardous industrial facilities.

node.title: In Houston, the new normal should include more efforts to reduce air pollution

children.text: Stay-at-home orders to slow the spread of COVID-19 resulted in Houstonians driving a lot less. But Houston hasnâ€™t stopped being an industrial city during the pandemic, which shows why reducing all air pollution is key to protecting public health.
